Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: NYU Center for Behavioral Statistics and the Study of Motivated Perception

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program, which is an NSF-wide program although each Directorate administers its own REU Site competition. This program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in an effort to introduce them to scientific research so as to encourage their continued engagement in the nation's scientific research and development enterprise. REU projects involve students in meaningful ways in ongoing research programs or in research projects designed especially for the purpose. The REU program is a major contributor to the NSF's goal of developing a diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce. The Social, Behavioral and Economic (SBE) sciences Directorate has awarded this REU Site grant to New York University with the goal to provide opportunities in STEM areas that increase engagement through the use of research-based learning communities. This REU Site integrates research and learning for undergraduate students using a group-learning approach to research and mentoring. Interns are diverse across race and gender and the project targets students at non research extensive universities. Research conducted at this REU Site aims to improve outcomes for minority group members. The students are trained and mentored through all stages of research, data collection, publication and presentation.

The purpose of the NYU REU Site project is to afford interns the opportunity to conduct research that could be theoretically transformative, translational, and interdisciplinary. The work in this project connects vision, group dynamics, psychophysiology, and cognition. This REU site designs research experiences using a learning community approach - one of the most effective means for increasing belonging-ness within the sciences. This site accepts 10 interns for 8-weeks each summer. The primary objective is to provide extensive, immersive training in basic and advanced behavioral statistics. The second objective of the site is to develop critical thinking skills in the science of motivated perception. Interns apply the theory of motivated perception by conducting original research in any two of the following areas: (1) interpersonal emotion, (2) politics, (3) health and fitness and (4) legal decision-making. In addition, interns are trained in social cognitive techniques including eye tracking, psychophysiology, and behavioral coding. The third objective is to increase a sense of belonging in STEM fields for underrepresented students which serves as a primary psychological factor predicting retention. Guided by PhD students and PIs, interns participate in research teams composed of peers and serve as the team leader for one of the projects. Further, interns present their research results at conferences and receive continued mentorship even after their REU term is over.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF REU NEW YORK UNIVERSITY Center for Behavioral Statistics and the Study of Motivated Perception held as its primary goal to advance higher education in science for underrepresented students. We received, across three years, 4432 applications and selected 30 to participate. Our accepted classes included 66% non-White students, and 57% underrepresented racial minorities.  We hit gender parity. Half were first generation, 60% were from non-PhD granting institutions, and 33% were from Historically Black Colleges or Hispanic-Serving institutions. One hundred percent of all eligible interns graduated with a bachelors degree. Half have applied for graduate school in science. Seven are currently in a PhD program, three completed or are currently in a Masters program, and seven are currently in or have completed research positions (e.g. lab manager) following graduation. Graduate degree institutions include: Stanford, University of Michigan, Rutgers, University of Virginia, University of Pennsylvania, Purdue, University of Texas at Austin, University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, Northwestern, University of California Irvine, University of Nevada.

 

Interns prepared manuscripts based on the data they collected, underwent a peer review process, and could use these manuscripts during their graduate application cycle as evidence of their advanced writing skills. Three interns have received acceptances on manuscripts they generated and submitted for publication in professional journals.

 

To facilitate preparation for graduate training interns participated in multiple panel discussions regarding the graduate application process and career options in psychology featuring lab alumni including an Associate Director of Planning & Strategy at a public relations firm, a neuroscience researcher, legal aid intern, NYC social worker, Harvard School of Public Health graduate student, Columbia University lab manager, clinical psychology researcher. These workshops were held in partnership with other groups including the Carnegie Mellon Leadership Alliance and the Dean’s Research Incubator Program at NYU.

 

As a primary objective, the REU site aimed to provide training in behavioral statistics. Interns completed multiple training workshops and received hands-on opportunities to analyze original data under the guidance of several PhD level statisticians, focusing on basic and advanced skills including regression, ANOVA, actor-partner interdependence models, moderated mediation analyses, and others. Pre to post-test measures on standardized tests found a 26% increase in scores on statistical training, and 30% of alumni who took the GRE scored in the top 25th percentile.

 

As a second objective, the REU site aimed to develop critical thinking skills in the interdisciplinary and translational science of motivated perception. Interns engaged in advanced discussions with 20 faculty from New York University, Harvard, Rutgers, Michigan, Cornell, Urbana Champaign, and other institutions about their current research. Pre to post-test measures found a 42%, increase in scores on evaluation of scientific research, and those who took the GRE scored on average in the 87th percentile on the analytic portion.

 

As the final objective, the REU site aimed to increase a sense of belonging in science for underrepresented populations, as feelings of belongingness predict retention. All students received additional scholarships to fund conference travel following the internship. All presented between one and three presentations of their original research at professional conferences. Interns shadowed researchers in several neuroscience and physiology labs. All interns served as team leaders on projects fostering greater investment. Pre to post-test measures indicated a 16% increase in feelings of belongingness in science. Moreover, using an AAC&U Rubric, we found mastery by all students in leadership and team development.  We continue to maintain a database to track alumni, maintain contact, and facilitate networking among alumni based on relevant career interests.
